snippet.textDisplay:
You know, I really want to stop driving vehicles. I really hate driving.


No not because it hurts the environment (although that's always at the back of my mind every time I have to drive for half an hour just to cash a check or buy some more Oreos, and then have to use the check I just cashed to afford the gas and Oreos), but because it's so expensive and stressful.


The only time I would ever really want to drive, ideally, in a perfect world, is when I have to travel through the African savanna or through a hell world from Warhammer 40K. I mean the Australian outback.
snippet.textOriginal:
You know, I really want to stop driving vehicles. I really hate driving.


No not because it hurts the environment (although that's always at the back of my mind every time I have to drive for half an hour just to cash a check or buy some more Oreos, and then have to use the check I just cashed to afford the gas and Oreos), but because it's so expensive and stressful.


The only time I would ever really want to drive, ideally, in a perfect world, is when I have to travel through the African savanna or through a hell world from _Warhammer 40K._ I mean the Australian outback.

snippet.textDisplay:
Researchers at the University of Oxford found that cutting meat and dairy products from your diet could reduce an individual's carbon footprint from food by up to 73 per cent. The new study, published in the journal Science, is one of the most comprehensive analyses to date into the detrimental effects farming can have on the environment and included data on nearly 40,000 farms in 119 countries.

The findings reveal that meat and dairy production is responsible for 60 per cent of agriculture’s greenhouse gas emissions, while the products themselves providing just 18 per cent of calories and 37 per cent of protein levels around the world.

Animal Agriculture has to go.
snippet.textOriginal:
Researchers at the University of Oxford found that cutting meat and dairy products from your diet could reduce an individual's carbon footprint from food by up to 73 per cent. The new study, published in the journal Science, is one of the most comprehensive analyses to date into the detrimental effects farming can have on the environment and included data on nearly 40,000 farms in 119 countries.

The findings reveal that meat and dairy production is responsible for 60 per cent of agriculture’s greenhouse gas emissions, while the products themselves providing just 18 per cent of calories and 37 per cent of protein levels around the world.

Animal Agriculture has to go.

snippet.textDisplay:
Correction: an electric vehicle powered by renewables still produces CO2. You need to take into account the carbon footprint of manufacturing the renewable energy source. The longer the lifespan and the lower the maintenance, the lower your gCO2/kWh ratio is.

IIRC, Hydro power is the worst CO2 producer of all renewables.

snippet.textDisplay:
While the intention and general information provided are really good, I feel like this video does not do a good job pointing out how plastic waste and carbon output are two different issues that often times cannot be tackled by the same measure. For example, while a plastic bag might have a much lesser carbon footprint, plastic waste takes decades, sometimes centuries to decompose while with paper bags it's less than a year.
I think it's still a very good video, I just hope that the takeaway of people watching is isn't just "plastic bags = good, paper bags = bad", because, like it is with everything in life, it's not that simple.
Cheers
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intention and general information provided are really good, I feel like this video does not do a good job pointing out how plastic waste and carbon output are two different issues that often times cannot be tackled by the same measure. For example, while a plastic bag might have a much lesser carbon footprint, plastic waste takes decades, sometimes centuries to decompose while with paper bags it's less than a year.
I think it's still a very good video, I just hope that the takeaway of people watching is isn't just "plastic bags = good, paper bags = bad", because, like it is with everything in life, it's not that simple.
Cheers

snippet.textDisplay:
China burns 3.8bn tonnes of coal each year, 85% of mined available supply. Your solar panel and hybrid is a drop in the ocean of CO2 China produces from their open stack coal generators.

Also , surveying CO2 emissions by capita is a stupid and flawed statistic, a person on a private island with a diesel generator could technically produce more CO2 , “ per capita “ than the entire country of japan.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Food is an extremely important point that you are missing in this good overview video, and a major point where regular people do have significant leverage for quick change.

Agriculture makes up about a fifth of CO2e (CO2 equivalent) emissions worldwide. Beef and dairy products are especially horrible, but other meat also emits a lot of CO2e. the main problems are that meat production wastes 85-90% of the calories that are fed to the animals, and that cows (herbivores in general) fart a lot. Methane is a very strong greenhouse gas, about 100x as bad as CO2 itself.



The german ministry for the environment published a study where they calculated emissions numbers. Top of the list:

1. Butter (24kg/CO2e per kg)

2. Beef (13 kg/CO2e per kg)

3. Cheese/Cream (8 kg/CO2e per kg)

4. frozen french fries (6 kg/CO2e per kg) (because of the energy intensive production and cooling chain, potato growing has almost no emissions)

5. Chocolate (3.5 kg/CO2e per kg)

6. pork and poultry (3.4 kg/CO2e per kg)


so buying 10 kg (~20 pounds) of butter emits as much as buying a new laptop. use plant-based fat instead (bonus: lower risk of heart disease)!
snippet.textOriginal:
Food is an extremely important point that you are missing in this good overview video, and a major point where regular people do have significant leverage for quick change. 

Agriculture makes up about a fifth of CO2e (CO2 equivalent) emissions worldwide. Beef and dairy products are especially horrible, but other meat also emits a lot of CO2e. the main problems are that meat production wastes 85-90% of the calories that are fed to the animals, and that cows (herbivores in general) fart a lot. Methane is a very strong greenhouse gas, about 100x as bad as CO2 itself. 



The german ministry for the environment published a study where they calculated emissions numbers. Top of the list: 

1. Butter (24kg/CO2e per kg) 

2. Beef (13 kg/CO2e per kg) 

3. Cheese/Cream (8 kg/CO2e per kg) 

4. frozen french fries (6 kg/CO2e per kg) (because of the energy intensive production and cooling chain, potato growing has almost no emissions) 

5. Chocolate (3.5 kg/CO2e per kg) 

6. pork and poultry (3.4 kg/CO2e per kg)


so buying 10 kg (~20 pounds) of butter emits as much as buying a new laptop. use plant-based fat instead (bonus: lower risk of heart disease)!

snippet.textDisplay:
Since you are focused on the climate, you should look into another major leading cause!
The negative effect on the climate of Methane is 23 times higher than the effect of CO2!! A cow does on overage release between 70 and 120 kg of Methane per year. According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) agriculture is responsible for 18% of the total release of greenhouse gases world-wide (this is more than the whole transportation sector).
